stream_context.summary: Kaze focuses on Course 11, an oil-rig level where Bowser’s minions stage a strike. Work covers textures (oil block, thwomps, windows), new enemy/prop models, protest dialogue, Goomba/Wiggler animations, N64 performance tuning, and planning Bowser’s office tower with an Act 3 boss cut-scene.

development_findings.summary: Course 11 now runs 25-29 FPS on real N64 after many small optimisations; only the distant tower is culled to avoid visual pop-in.
development_findings.quote: For the worst part of the level, 25 FPS… in a level like this, I’m fine with that.

development_findings.summary: A scaling pop-in trick hides distant enemies: they shrink into the ground when out of range, then rise when the player approaches.
development_findings.quote: You see how he smoothly scaled, and now when I come close, he comes back out of the ground.

development_findings.summary: Oil block enemy model created; eyes changed to white for readability and teeth dirtied to match oily theme.
Thwomps in the protest will hop in place to convey anger; texture colours desaturated to avoid over-saturation complaints.
development_findings.quote: Maybe they should be like hopping up and down—yes, they will all be hopping.

development_findings.summary: Goomba ‘builder’ receives new sit, fall, and protest animations; will appear flattened with a squashed dialogue box gag.
development_findings.quote: Got flattened to a pancake—imagine the face of my wife when I slide under the front door tonight.

development_findings.summary: Bowser’s tower interior design finalised: lobby with sleeping receptionist, elevator cut-scene, secret shaft for a Yoshi coin, top-floor office where Bowser rants across acts.
development_findings.quote: Act 3: you enter, he’s stomping in a tantrum, sends a strike breaker… when you exit, the plaza is empty, music stops, and the block eats you.

development_findings.summary: Strike-breaker boss (large oil block) will only appear in Act 3 after Bowser’s rant; player is swallowed and warped to a separate arena.
Protest dialogue system implemented; 10 NPCs assigned bespoke lines using pun-heavy scripts generated via ChatGPT and manual edits.
development_findings.quote: We’re more than just a stepping stone—squished at work, squished by Mario, enough!

development_findings.summary: Window texture for Bowser’s office taken from Paper Mario Bowser’s Castle and adjusted for CI4 palette efficiency.
Future technical milestone: quaternion animation system to enable smoother multiplayer; target minimum 20 FPS split-screen.
development_findings.quote: I’m planning to add multiplayer after we have quaternion animations.

context_findings.summary: Kaze prefers in-game replayability via player skill growth over formal New Game Plus or unlockables.
context_findings.quote: You get better at Mario, you find new shortcuts—that’s replayability.

context_findings.summary: He avoids meme inserts to keep tone consistent, calling random meme cameos ‘cringe’.
context_findings.quote: Unless it’s specifically a meme hack, you should not do it.

context_findings.summary: Kaze jokes about piracy and software cost, reflecting pragmatic but humorous stance on tooling expenses.
context_findings.quote: I almost paid for WinRAR… then astral ray bit flips put every VGM on my USB.

context_findings.summary: Expresses concern over legalities of selling OST cartridges due to shared Nintendo samples and Yoshi trademark; would consult a lawyer.
context_findings.quote: I would have to look into whether it’s legal to sell the OST if it has a few samples that are also used in Mario 64.

context_findings.summary: Floats long-term idea of a professionally organised Ocarina of Time hack with open contributor roles and GitHub workflow.
context_findings.quote: We should develop an Ocarina of Time hack… role play as a professional game studio.

biobak.summary: Offers to redo textures (oil block, windows), supplies angry Koopa eyes, and generally provides quick art fixes.
biobak.quote: I’ll send you two textures and then you can do what you want.

zeina.summary: Works on complex Wiggler rig and provides Goomba builder animations; collaborates live with Kaze on bone hierarchy issues.
zeina.quote: I’m working on just trying to get a good walk cycle going on… one segment at a time so it doesn’t fry my brain cells.

key_stories.title: Building the Protest Dialogue
key_stories.summary: Kaze needed punchy protest lines for thwomps and koopas. Initial ChatGPT outputs felt too long, so he iterated prompts, added context, and mixed in Biobak’s puns until the team laughed.
key_stories.challenge: Writing ten unique, humorous lines that suit each enemy type.
key_stories.process: Prompted ChatGPT, refined context, filtered results, and supplemented with manual jokes from Biobak and chat.
key_stories.outcome: Final set of concise, pun-laden dialogues implemented with sound effects and even a squashed text box for the flattened Goomba.
key_stories.key_quote: This environment is crushing, and believe me, I know a thing or two about crushing.

key_stories.title: Flattened Goomba Gag
key_stories.summary: They wanted a visual joke where a Goomba gets permanently flattened during the strike.
key_stories.challenge: Create bespoke animations and a matching dialogue box that appears squished.
key_stories.process: Zeina animated sit-fall-flatten cycle; Kaze added code to scale the dialogue box on X-axis and tied it to Act 3 logic.
key_stories.outcome: Working in-game gag that instantly resonated with the team.
key_stories.key_quote: The dialogue box is squished but the text is not—let’s fix that.

key_stories.title: Optimising Course 11 for Real Hardware
key_stories.summary: Previous streams suffered low framerate; Kaze applied numerous micro-optimisations.
key_stories.challenge: Huge open area with minimal culling dragged N64 below 20 FPS.
key_stories.process: Reduced texture formats, backface-culled only distant tower, streamlined geometry, and tested on console.
key_stories.outcome: Steady 25–29 FPS in worst-case camera views, acceptable for release.
key_stories.key_quote: For the worst part of the level, 27 is fine.

open_questions.context: Kaze sketched lobby, elevator, secret vent, and top office but no final asset list or scale.
questions: What architectural style and colour palette will the interior use to feel both ‘industrial office’ and ‘Bowser’?
How will you telegraph the secret elevator escape so players discover the Yoshi coin organically?
Will the receptionist NPC have gameplay relevance beyond flavour?
Any unique music or ambience planned for interior versus exterior?

open_questions.context: Boss is envisioned as a giant oil block that swallows Mario after Act 3 cut-scene.
questions: What moveset, weak points, or puzzle hooks differentiate the strike-breaker from earlier bosses?
Will protest themes influence boss phases or environment hazards?
How will camera and collision behave inside the ‘swallowed’ arena?

open_questions.context: Kaze plans to add multiplayer once quaternion animations land, targeting 20 FPS.
questions: What gameplay modes (co-op, race, battle) are envisioned?
How will network or split-screen be handled on N64 hardware?
Does multiplayer influence level design (e.g., wider platforms, separate spawn points)?

open_questions.topic: Legal Path for OST & Physical Merch
open_questions.context: Kaze considers selling OST cartridges and boxed manuals but worries about Nintendo samples and trademarks.
questions: Have you identified sample libraries used in Mario 64 to license them independently?
Would re-recording tracks with new instruments sidestep legal risk?
What is the contingency plan if lawyers advise against selling physical media?

open_questions.context: He floated a studio-style community project two-to-three years out.
questions: What lessons from RTYI’s development inform this structure?
How would roles, milestones, and QA be formalised?
What motivates you to simulate a studio instead of continuing informal streaming?
How will Nintendo’s legal stance affect such a public endeavour?
